benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/bundles/{bundleId}/tags - Remove tags from bundle

covered: Valid Deletion: Success scenarios for deleting all tags (no tagDef), deleting specific tagDef(s), and deleting when bundle has no tags (TC01, TC02, TC04, TC16).
Path param validation: Invalid bundleId format (400) and non-existent bundleId (404) are covered (TC05, TC06).

Query parameter validation: Invalid tagDef UUID, partial invalid/valid tagDef mix, empty array regression, extra unexpected query params, and very large numbers of tagDef values are covered (TC11, TC12, TC13, TC16, TC02).
Header validation & audit headers: Required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy being missing is tested; optional headers X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment are exercised (TC03, TC08).
Concurrency & performance: Concurrency/race condition behavior and performance under many concurrent deletes and very large tag sets / timeout behavior are covered (TC15, TC18).
Integration & consistency: Post-deletion verification via GET to confirm persistence and consistency is included (TC17).
Error & availability handling: Service unavailable scenario (503) and unauthorized access (401) are covered (TC10, TC09).
Security/input sanitization: XSS/SQL injection in headers is considered (TC14).
gaps: Soft delete semantics: No test verifies whether tags are soft-deleted (marked deleted) vs permanently removed or that deleted records remain queryable via admin endpoints.
Server-side error handling (5xx) beyond 503 and timeout: There are no tests that simulate internal server errors (500) or database failures to verify graceful handling and consistent responses.
Produces / response headers: The story says "Produces: application/json" but tests do not assert response Content-Type, nor other relevant response headers (e.g., Audit-ID, Date).
Idempotency / repeated deletes: Although concurrency is tested, explicit idempotency of repeated DELETEs (delete same tag(s) multiple times sequentially) is not explicitly covered.
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests for rate limiting, throttling, or behavior when the API is hit rapidly beyond allowed quotas.
Caching behavior: No checks for caching-related headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or cache semantics for GET used in integration checks.

Authorization detail coverage: There is a negative unauthorized test (401) but no tests for forbidden (403) scenarios or for scoped permissions (different roles) to validate fine-grained authorization.
Boundary/error message assertions: Tests often assert status codes but many do not assert structured error payload contents (error codes, error type, machine-readable fields) or their schema.
Malformed query encoding & duplication: No tests for duplicated tagDef parameters, URL-encoded values, or malformed query string encodings.

Pagination / large-list handling in GET: While delete for large tag counts is tested, there are no tests covering pagination or how GET /bundles handles very large tag lists used in integration checks.
recommendations: Add a test that verifies soft-delete vs permanent-delete semantics: check the underlying tag storage (or admin read) to confirm whether records are flagged or removed.
Introduce server-error simulations (500) and database-failure tests to ensure the API returns consistent error responses and does not leave data in an inconsistent state.
Assert response headers: add assertions for Content-Type (application/json) and any audit or caching headers returned by the DELETE and subsequent GET calls.
Add explicit idempotency tests: sequentially call DELETE twice for the same tag set and assert first returns 204 and second also returns 204 (or documented behavior).
Add rate-limiting tests: check behavior when exceeding request quotas (429) or how the system throttles burst traffic.
Add tests for authorization scopes/roles and 403 Forbidden scenarios in addition to 401, to validate permission boundaries.
Enrich error-response assertions: validate structure and content of error responses (message, code, field, etc.) for 4xx and 5xx cases.
Cover malformed and duplicated query parameters and URL-encoded tagDef values to ensure robust parsing of the tagDef multi-valued parameter.
Include caching and pagination checks for GET integration calls (ETag, Cache-Control) and validate that large tag lists are returned/paginated correctly when used for verification.
Add a test to verify behaviour when duplicate tagDef values are supplied and when tagDef values include whitespace or mixed-case UUIDs to validate normalization rules.
